quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: Forces Fundamentals and Newton's Laws (50 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Introduction to Forces, Newton's First and Second Laws

questions.question: What is a force?
options: The amount of matter in an object
A push or pull that can change an object's motion
The speed at which an object moves
questions.explanation: A force is defined as a push or pull that can cause an object to accelerate, change direction, or deform.

questions.question: Which of the following is a contact force?
questions.explanation: Friction requires physical contact between surfaces, making it a contact force.

questions.question: Newton's First Law of Motion is also known as:
questions.explanation: Newton's First Law describes inertia - an object's tendency to resist changes in its motion.

questions.question: According to Newton's First Law, what happens to an object at rest when no net force acts on it?
questions.explanation: An object at rest stays at rest unless acted upon by a net external force.

questions.question: What is inertia?
options: The force of gravity on an object
An object's resistance to changes in motion
The amount of friction between surfaces
questions.explanation: Inertia is the property of matter that resists changes in velocity.

questions.question: Two people push a car in the same direction with forces of 300 N and 400 N. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: When forces act in the same direction, add them: 300 N + 400 N = 700 N.

questions.question: A book is pushed with 20 N east and pulled with 15 N west. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: Opposite directions: 20 N east - 15 N west = 5 N east.

questions.question: Newton's Second Law states that:
options: For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction
An object at rest stays at rest
Energy cannot be created or destroyed
questions.explanation: F = ma is the mathematical expression of Newton's Second Law.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of force?
questions.explanation: The newton (N) is the SI unit of force, defined as 1 kg·m/s².

questions.question: A 5 kg object accelerates at 3 m/s². What net force acts on it?
questions.explanation: F = ma = 5 kg × 3 m/s² = 15 N.

questions.question: Which object has the greatest inertia?
questions.explanation: Inertia depends on mass - the bowling ball has the most mass and thus the greatest inertia.

questions.question: A car moves at constant velocity. What can be said about the net force acting on it?
options: Net force equals the car's weight
Net force equals the engine force
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means no acceleration, so by F=ma, net force must be zero.

questions.question: A 10 N force and a 6 N force act in opposite directions on an object. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: 10 N - 6 N = 4 N in the direction of the larger force.

questions.question: What acceleration will a 4 kg object have if a 12 N net force acts on it?
questions.explanation: a = F/m = 12 N / 4 kg = 3 m/s².

questions.question: Which scenario demonstrates Newton's First Law?
options: A book sliding to a stop on a table
A ball falling faster as it drops
questions.explanation: The book demonstrates inertia - it continues moving until friction (external force) stops it.

questions.question: A force of 25 N gives an object an acceleration of 5 m/s². What is the object's mass?
questions.explanation: m = F/a = 25 N / 5 m/s² = 5 kg.

questions.question: What is the net force on an object with balanced forces?
questions.explanation: Balanced forces cancel each other out, resulting in zero net force.

questions.question: Which force always acts opposite to the direction of motion?
questions.explanation: Friction always opposes the direction of motion or attempted motion.

questions.question: A shopping cart is pushed with 30 N forward and experiences 10 N friction backward. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: 30 N forward - 10 N backward = 20 N forward.

questions.question: What happens to acceleration if mass increases but net force stays the same?
questions.explanation: From a = F/m, if mass increases and F is constant, acceleration decreases.

questions.question: A 2 kg object experiences a net force of 8 N. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: a = F/m = 8 N / 2 kg = 4 m/s².

questions.question: Which is an example of a non-contact force?
options: A book resting on a table
A car tire on the road
questions.explanation: Magnetic force can act at a distance without physical contact.

questions.question: If the net force on an object is zero, the object must be:
options: Either at rest or moving at constant velocity
questions.explanation: Zero net force means no acceleration, so the object could be at rest OR moving at constant velocity.

questions.question: A 1,200 kg car accelerates at 2 m/s². What net force is required?
What is required to change an object's state of motion?
questions.explanation: A net external force is required to change an object's motion (accelerate it).

questions.question: A person pushes a box with 50 N east while friction acts with 15 N west. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: 50 N east - 15 N west = 35 N east.

questions.question: Which has more inertia: a loaded truck or the same truck when empty?
questions.explanation: The loaded truck has more mass, therefore more inertia.

questions.question: If you double the net force on an object, what happens to its acceleration?
questions.explanation: From F = ma, if mass is constant and F doubles, acceleration must double.

questions.question: A 0.5 kg ball is thrown with a force of 20 N. What is its acceleration?
Why do passengers lurch forward when a bus suddenly stops?
questions.explanation: Inertia causes passengers to continue moving forward when the bus stops suddenly.

questions.question: Three forces act on an object: 10 N north, 10 N south, and 5 N east. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: North and south forces cancel (10 N - 10 N = 0), leaving only 5 N east.

questions.question: What mass would accelerate at 4 m/s² under a 20 N force?
questions.explanation: m = F/a = 20 N / 4 m/s² = 5 kg.

questions.question: Which force keeps planets in orbit around the sun?
questions.explanation: Gravity is the attractive force between masses that keeps planets in orbit.

questions.question: A hockey puck slides across frictionless ice. What is the net force on it?
options: Equal to the push that started it
questions.explanation: No friction means no net force, so it continues at constant velocity (Newton's First Law).

questions.question: If mass is constant and net force triples, what happens to acceleration?
questions.explanation: From a = F/m, if F triples and m is constant, acceleration triples.

questions.question: What is the weight of a 60 kg person on Earth? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Weight = mg = 60 kg × 9.8 m/s² = 588 N.

questions.question: A book rests on a table. Why doesn't it accelerate downward due to gravity?
options: Gravity stops acting on stationary objects
The table pushes up with equal force
questions.explanation: The normal force from the table balances gravity, resulting in zero net force.

questions.question: A net force of 15 N acts on a 3 kg object. After 4 seconds, how much has its velocity changed?
questions.explanation: a = F/m = 15 N / 3 kg = 5 m/s². Δv = a × t = 5 m/s² × 4 s = 20 m/s.

questions.question: Which requires more force to accelerate: a bicycle or a car?
questions.explanation: The car has more mass, so according to F = ma, it requires more force for the same acceleration.

questions.question: A 500 g object accelerates at 6 m/s². What net force acts on it?
What is the net force on a falling object at terminal velocity?
questions.explanation: At terminal velocity, air resistance equals weight, so net force is zero and acceleration stops.

questions.question: A force of 100 N gives object A acceleration of 4 m/s². The same force gives object B acceleration of 2 m/s². Which has more mass?
questions.explanation: m = F/a. Object B: 100 N / 2 m/s² = 50 kg. Object A: 100 N / 4 m/s² = 25 kg. Object B has more mass.

questions.question: Why is it harder to push a full shopping cart than an empty one?
questions.explanation: The full cart has more mass and thus more inertia, resisting changes to its motion.

questions.question: A rocket in deep space fires its engines, producing 50,000 N of thrust. If its mass is 10,000 kg, what is its acceleration?
What is the net force on a 2 kg object that is accelerating at 3 m/s²?
questions.explanation: F = ma = 2 kg × 3 m/s² = 6 N.

questions.question: If an object's mass is halved while net force remains constant, what happens to acceleration?
questions.explanation: a = F/m, so if m is halved, acceleration doubles.

questions.question: A person stands on a scale in an elevator. When will the scale read less than their actual weight?
options: When the elevator moves at constant speed
questions.explanation: Downward acceleration reduces the normal force, making the scale read less.

questions.question: What is the mass of an object that weighs 196 N on Earth? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
A car going around a curve at constant speed is:
questions.explanation: Changing direction requires acceleration, even if speed is constant.

questions.question: A 0.2 kg baseball is thrown with 40 N of force. What is its acceleration?
Which statement about force and motion is correct?
questions.explanation: Net force causes acceleration (change in velocity), not velocity itself.

questions.question: A 1,500 kg car accelerates from 0 to 27 m/s (60 mph) in 8 seconds. What is the average net force?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong understanding of forces and Newton's Laws.
scoreMessages.70: Very Good! You understand most concepts but should review net force calculations.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort! Focus on practicing F=ma problems and force combinations.
scoreMessages.0: Keep trying! Review the basic definitions of forces and Newton's Laws.
